title: As of 9 May 2020, how many COVID-19 related deaths will have occurred in Louisiana, as reported by COVID Tracker?
preds: Looks like it will add up to another 100 by the 9th, to be at around 2300.
really slow increase. only external factors seem to be able to take the forecast out of the 2000-2750 bucket.

Based on current weekly trends, it appears to be in the neighborhood of 2200 for the 9th. Adjusting to put more weight on the 2k to 2.75k range. Previous

About 300 to 400 deaths per week based on previous datasets
Was linearly tracking to 2500 since early April.  Now on pace for 2,382.
Only a reclassification of prior deaths can put the number over 2750, and only a miracle can keep it under 2000.

Updating model [1] with today's data. See original post [2] for methodology. May 9th forecast: 2,203 
Previous May 9th forecasts: 2,046 | 2,155 | 2,097 | 1,982 | 1,799 | 2,259 | 2,225 [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=483192899
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1020814

1862 deaths as of 4/30.  Rough average of 50 deaths per day. 1862+450 puts the likeliest range between 2,000 and 2,750. A result of <2000 implies the death rate dropping to around 15 per day. This seems unlikely.  On the other end the death rate would have to accelerate to 80+/day to be >2,750.  Data Quality Grade of B obviates any more precise calculation.
There seem to be some big lags and gaps in the reported daily numbers.
About 300 to 400 deaths per week based on previous datasets
Seems like only change in measurements can land it outside 2000-2750
Updating odds as data follows projected data

Ok crowd consensus is high but loosening social restrictions might spike upward. Put more in bin 2 but rather cover bin 3 some.
Raised likelihood because the projected datatrends were followed, and came out a bit short. Currently, projected deaths on May 9th will be 2440.

Probability in top two brackets is basically all uncertainty of potential change of measurement criteria

Previous May 9th forecasts: 2,046 | 2,155 | 2,097 | 1,982 [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=483192899
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1020814

FWIW: Reported Louisiana virus deaths have dropped below 30 the last two days (reporting through 4/27/20).  Some restrictions may be lifted soon. https://www.nola.com/news/coronavirus/article_7cb2af1c-6414-11ea-b729-93612370dd94.html https://www.wdsu.com/article/coronavirus-updates-in-louisiana-27068-covid-19-cases-across-the-state-1697-deaths-reported/32282285#

Nearly linear growth since 01/04/2020, with a trendline of y = 58.467x + 183.05; where y is the number of deaths in Louisiana  and x is the number of days since 01/04/2020. Solving for y = 39 (May 9th) yields 2463 (+/- 5) deaths, with a minimum deviation of 0.0% and a maximum deviation of 6.7% (average 0.2%). Therefore the number is most likely to be between 2298 and 2628. It's unlikely (1/26; 3.8% odds) that May 9th will be an outlier beyond 2750.
Adjusting model to be a bit less confident due to my divergence from the crowd.

Updating model [1] with today's data. See original post [2] for methodology. Fearing it might be a bit overconfident. May 9th forecast: 1,982
Previous May 9th forecasts: 2,046 | 2,155 | 2,097 [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=483192899
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1020814

1670 coronavirus deaths reported in Louisiana as of 4/26/20. (https://www.fox8live.com/2020/04/24/la-dept-health-cases-covid-deaths-reported/) . (I count) 13 remaining days (of data) for this question (4/27-5/9/20). An average of 25.4 deaths per day for this upcoming period will equal 2000 deaths as of 5/9.  Over the most recent 11-day period Louisiana has averaged approx. 51.5 deaths/day, with a range of 26 to 77 per day. (https://covidtracking.com/data/state/louisiana). It seems that a significant downward trend in (recent) daily deaths will need to occur to avoid exceeding 2000 deaths over the remaining time period. At the recent, simple avg. rate indicated above, approx. 670 more deaths may occur by 5/9/20 (holding other factors and influences). (13 X 51.5)

Exponential functions, like compound interest, work their magic over long periods of time.  Two weeks doesn't qualify as a long period of time.  So we can just calculate the average daily deaths required to fall into any given range by May 9.  26 to 79 deaths per each remaining day gets us to a total on May 9 of 2000 to 2750.

Updating model [1] with today's data. See original post [2] for methodology. Fearing it might be a bit overconfident. May 9th forecast: 2,097

Forecasts are based on current rates

Small forecast increase to the 2000-2750 question 'bin' for now, as a higher number of most-recent deaths (61, one day) are being reported than I had anticipated. https://www.wdsu.com/article/coronavirus-updates-in-louisiana-26140-covid-19-cases-in-state-1601-deaths-reported/32267309#
As Louisiana is still peaking and the %death rate is above average of that reported by WHO, I expect to see the numbers raising.
Fairly predictable at this point, Louisiana is past the worst, at least for now

Something is not right in data from Louisiana. They get only positive results 6 days in a row and NO negatives (the latter are usually the majority in all other datasets). Or they started just not reporting negatives? It looks the state passed the peak in both, positive results and deaths. But deaths were creeping up lately and may skew the final results up. My logistic model puts the estimate above 2,000, but in deference to IHME, I put some probability in the 1st bucket, maybe more than I should have.
If the trend remains linear as it has been since early April it will be 2500.

Using a similar model [1] and methodology [2] as other questions to linearly project based on sloped growth since peak with adjustments for day-of-week variation in reporting. May 9th Forecast: 2,046 I'm a bit higher than IMHE [3] but well within their 95% interval. I'm lower than the matching Metaculus question [4]. I suspect the organizers of that expert panel are getting input from both Metaculus and GJO crowds. Or else GJO just is interesting in tracking how its crowd does relative to the experts for its own purposes. Interesting time to be a forecaster. [2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1020792
[3] https://covid19.healthdata.org/united-states-of-america/louisiana
[4] https://pandemic.metaculus.com/questions/4190/lrt-14-as-of-saturday-may-9-2020-how-many-covid-19-related-deaths-will-have-occurred-in-louisiana/
There are enough people who take the situation seriously.  The death toll won't rise that fast.
Not enough time to do another calculation today. Just an eyeball estimate.

Cursory analysis/comment: Louisiana has 25,739 total confirmed cases as of 4/23/20. The state is averaging 591 reported new cases per day over the last two weeks (4/8-23/20 inclusive, 9456 cases total), with a more recent downtrend (avg. of 432 new cases in the last five days). Source used: https://www.theadvertiser.com/story/news/2020/03/26/coronavirus-louisiana-see-covid-19-cases-confirmed-each-day/2916457001/ 1,540 total coronavirus-related deaths have been reported as of 4/23/20, yielding an over-simplified current total cases "mortality rate" of around 0.06. (1540/25739.) (https://www.wdsu.com/article/coronavirus-updates-in-louisiana-25-739-covid-19-cases-in-state-1540-deaths-reported/32253126) Louisiana's governor and others reportedly are aiming to reopen the state's economy in stages, likely beginning on May 1 -- a possible "wild card" for the question. It appears that social distancing and masks in public will at least (continue to) be encouraged (..perhaps strongly): https://www.thenewsstar.com/story/news/2020/04/22/louisiana-coronavirus-john-bel-edwards-covid-19-update-cases-ventilators/3003313001/. 
More testing is also planned. (https://www.msn.com/en-us/health/wellness/coronavirus-updates-in-louisiana-25739-covid-19-cases-in-state-1540-deaths-reported/ar-BB136l5q) (FWIW: If testing is quickly ramped-up it could increase the number of (new) detected cases in the near-term, affecting some simple calculations here. Not consistent evidence of increased testing yet, though: https://covidtracking.com/data/state/louisiana) Initial forecast suggests that the state's coronavirus numbers will most likely continue to slowly decline, but still could be fairly close to the figures recited above for the upcoming period. Given the recent downturn in new cases, arbitrarily using 80% of the 4/8-23/20 numbers above to make the first forecast. Will adjust as needed.  (9456 (recent) cases X .8 = about 7,565 new cases by 5/9/20. 7565 X 0.06 rough "mortality rate" = about 454 new deaths by 5/9/20. (1540 current (total) deaths + 454 new deaths = about 1,994 total projected deaths by 5/9/20.))
Take the average daily deaths for the last 9 days and multiply by the remaining 16 days gives 2475 deaths.
Louisiana death rate is following a 3rd degree polynomial with an R^2 = .9981 and a projected total of 2283 on May 9, 2020.
